messageBody:
re - testing private methods

>I have been assigned the task of pushing our development team toward
>unit testing.  I have been working with JUnit for a few weeks now but
>continue to struggle with one issue.  it seems to me there is tension
>between unit testing and my preferred API.  for a given class I would
>like to expose only a handful of methods, yet do not want to forfeit
>testing my private methods.  my feeling is that I should be concerned
>with continually testing those methods, and yet fail to see why I
>should expose methods which are meaningless outside the "blackbox".
>
>perhaps I am missing something obvious about good design.

It has been said that OO unit testing, writing code test-first, and applying the XP simplicity rules ( see http://www.xprogramming.com/xpmag/expEmergentDesign.htm ) tends to result in smaller classes with public methods.

Basically, you refactor a class that has lots of private methods into multiple classes with mostly public methods. Instances of those new classes are now used as private members, parameters, or local variables of public methods, in the original class.

Original Rules of Simple Design
1. Run all the tests
2. Contain no duplicate code
3. Express all the ideas the author wants to express
4. Minimize classes and methods

An Alternative Formulation, due to Alan Shalloway
1. Runs all the tests
2. Follows once and only once rule / "contains no duplicate code"
3. Has high cohesion (clarity)
4. Has loose coupling
